title: Part A: Thesis
stimulusHtml:
A thesis is an arguable statement about a subject.

The thesis may appear anywhere within the essay.

This is a partial task with fewer sources than the synthesis task in the summative exam. The prompt is designed for students to practice drafting first responses to a timed synthesis question. While the task is shortened for sake of practicing synthesis, at this point in the course students should already have enough experience with developing and conveying claims to compose clear, focused thesis statements.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
Responds to the prompt with a defensible thesis that may establish a line of reasoning.

title: Part B: Evidence and Commentary
stimulusHtml:
Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the second point in this row.

Commentary connects the evidence and reasoning to the thesis.

Since there are only four sources—including only one visual (quantitative) source—and all sources should be accessible for most students, they should be able to spend ample time with each of the sources as they synthesize them into their own argument. Also, because students are only listing evidence from the sources that supports their thesis and then briefly explaining how that evidence might figure into their argument, please consider that they may not necessarily develop their commentary enough to earn all of the points. This is why, for this unit, they can only earn 2 of the 4 points in this row. In some cases, student responses may exceed the criteria for these 2 points on this formative assessment. Students will be able to earn up to 4 points in this row in later units and on the summative AP Exam.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:

The response meets both of the following criteria:

Provides evidence from or references at least two of the provided sources.

AND

Evidence provided must be relevant to the subject of the prompt.

The response meets both of the following criteria:

Provides evidence from or references at least three of the provided sources.

AND

Evidence provided must be relevant to the subject of the prompt.

title: Part C: Sophistication
stimulusHtml:
Demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation by:

1. Situating the argument within a broader context, recognizing the implications of the argument.

Although this is a shortened task, students may understand enough about the audience and context of an argument by this point in the course to be able to earn the point in this row. While students’ attempts to do things necessary for earning this point may be rudimentary at this stage, you might still consider awarding this point if you can see how these attempts at greater rhetorical sophistication could—if more fully developed—advance their argument in some way.
descriptions: Response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.
Response demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.
